<information>Doc 1(Title: "The Dark Side of Anonymity on the Internet") The Dark Side of Anonymity on the Internet The Internet has provided a platform for people to express themselves freely, but it has also given rise to a dark side where individuals hide behind anonymity to spread negativity, harassment, and misinformation. This phenomenon, often referred to as "trolling," can have serious consequences for both individuals and society at large. Trolls may post defamatory comments, engage in cyberbullying, or spread false information under the guise of anonymity, making it difficult to hold them accountable for their actions. This behavior not only harms the victims but also erodes trust in online communities and platforms.
Doc 2(Title: "The Ethics of Anonymity in Online Discourse") The Ethics of Anonymity in Online Discourse While anonymity can protect individuals from retaliation and enable free speech, it also poses ethical concerns. Posting negative comments anonymously can lead to a lack of accountability and responsibility. It may encourage individuals to say things they would not say if their identity were known, potentially causing harm to others. Moreover, anonymous negative comments can contribute to a toxic online environment, discouraging constructive dialogue and fostering division. Therefore, while anonymity has its benefits, it is important to consider the potential risks and act ethically when participating in online discussions.
</information>

Doc 1(Title: "Dirty COW") Dirty COW Dirty COW (""Dirty copy-on-write"") is a computer security vulnerability for the Linux kernel that affects all Linux-based operating systems including Android. It is a local privilege escalation bug that exploits a race condition in the implementation of the copy-on-write mechanism in the kernel's memory-management subsystem. The vulnerability was discovered by Phil Oester. Because of the race condition, with the right timing, a local attacker can exploit the copy-on-write mechanism to turn a read-only mapping of a file into a writable mapping. Although it is a local privilege escalation, remote attackers can use it in conjunction with other exploits
Doc 2(Title: "Dirty COW") privileges are escalated, whether by genuine or ingenuine means – such as by using the Dirty COW exploit – the user can modify usually unmodifiable binaries and files. If a malicious individual could use the Dirty COW vulnerability to escalate their permissions, they could change a file, such as /bin/bash, so that it performs an additional, unexpected functions, such as a keylogger. When a user starts a program which has been infected, they will inadvertently allow the malicious code to run. If the exploit targets a program which is run with root privileges, the exploit will enjoy those same privileges.

A highly reactive, inflammable, and colorless liquid, dimethylmercury is one of the strongest known neurotoxins, with a quantity of less than 0.1 mL capable of inducing severe mercury poisoning, and is easily absorbed through the skin. Dimethylmercury is capable of permeating many materials, including plastic and rubber compounds. The toxicity of the compound was demonstrated by the death of heavy metal chemist Karen Wetterhahn, who died 10 months after a single exposure permeated through her disposable latex gloves.
